page.title: 02LAND USE IN FARNLEY.
page.content: This area is on the Western edge of the Yorkshire Coalfield, where it merges into the Pennine foothills. The area is drained by the Farnley and Pudsey becks which are tributaries of the River Aire. Being close to the Coal-field, there is much evidence of 19th century mining. Good quality ironstone has been found in the area and New Farnley owes its existence to the mineral resources found here. The area is now predominantly residential and light industrial, though there is a number of farms in the south and west. Stock raising is the norm but there is some arable and a little market gardening. There is little woodland, such as there is being mostly in the public parks at Armley, Wortley and Farnley.
